thread.title: Police called after Airbnb renters thought to be robbers
thread.title_full: Police called after Airbnb renters thought to be robbers

title: Police called after Airbnb renters thought to be robbers
text:
Police called after Airbnb renters thought to be robbers Last updated 12:53, October 13 2015 Trill DeGrasse Tyson/Twitter 
Stef Grant posted this selfie toTwitter after police officers responded to a call because neighbours suspected the Airbnb renters were robbers. 
An Airbnb rental turned into a nightmare for a musician after neighbours called the police to the property because they allegedly thought the guests were robbing the home. 
The incident was live-tweeted out to the world by the musician, known as STEFisDOPE. 
The rapper and four other friends were staying at the property before performing in the US town of Decatur, Georgia. Views from Zone 6. pic.twitter.com/INOiOsHM2f â€” Trill DeGrasse Tyson (@STEFisDOPE) October 8, 2015 
Upon arrival STEFisDOPE shared images of their accomodation on social media, but it wasn't long before the police arrived. 3. Neighbors think we're robbing the place. Cops pull up ðŸ˜‚ pic.twitter.com/cUSwsl9Fch â€” Trill DeGrasse Tyson (@STEFisDOPE) October 9, 2015 
"People thought we were robbing the house," STEFisDOPE said in a video. Although he seemed in quite good spirits about the ordeal 
Speaking to Slate.com, STEFisDOPE (real name Stef Grant) explained the situation. 
"We got a call from the neighbors saying you guys were breaking into the house and robbing the place,'" Grant said. "Our eyes all got huge - we were like, 'No, this is an Airbnb! The owner knows we're here, we've been in contact with her!" 
After police realised their mistake they left the property without further issue, although the neighbours were still not convinced as a "random neighbour just opens the door on us," STEFisDOPE tweeted. 4. Random neighbor just opens the door on us lol ðŸ˜­ pic.twitter.com/a8rI5V84Oy â€” Trill DeGrasse Tyson (@STEFisDOPE) October 9, 2015 
After the ordeal, Grant told Slate.com that it "wasn't totally unexpected". 
"We're black kids in this Leave it to Beaver neighbourhood, you know?"
